questions.question: An ultrasound of a 28-year-old woman with monochorionic-diamniotic twins reveals a significant difference in amniotic fluid levels between the two sacs. Twin A has polyhydramnios, while Twin B has oligohydramnios. Which of the following symptoms would NOT be found in Twin A?
questions.explanation: twins. Hypovolemia is a symptom seen in the donor twin, hypervolemia is a symptom present in the recipient twin. The condition arises from a vascular connection within the shared placenta of the twins Recipient twin Donor twin Polyhydramnios Polycythemia Hypertension Hypervolemia Increased risk of congestive heart failure and hydrops Oligohydramnios Anemia Hypotension Hypovolemia Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 847-49

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents to your clinic at 20 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She mentions increased fatigue, shortness of breath, and noticeable swelling in her legs and feet. On examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and there is no proteinuria. A recent ultrasound confirmed a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. Which of the following physiological changes is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation: accommodate the increased metabolic demands of both fetuses. One of the major adaptations is an increase in cardiac output , which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and shortness of breath. Physiological Changes in Twin Pregnancy: Increased Blood Volume: Twin pregnancies are associated with greater blood volume (50 - 60%) than singleton pregnancies (40 - 50%). Decreased Peripheral Vascular Resistance: There is a decrease in PVR compared to singleton pregnancies. Cardiac Output: The cardiac output in twin pregnancies is significantly higher than in singleton pregnancies. Blood Pressure: Despite the increased blood volume and cardiac output, the overall blood pressure in twin pregnancies may not rise proportionally due to the decreased PVR. Pre-eclampsia: Twin pregnancies have a higher incidence of pre-eclampsia. The decreased PVR and increased blood volume can exacerbate the endothelial dysfunction characteristic of pre-eclampsia. Uterine growth in multifetal pregnancies is significantly greater than in singleton pregnancies. Particularly in monozygotic twins, excessive amniotic fluid can accumulate quickly. The expanding uterus can significantly compress and displace the maternal abdominal organs and lungs. In rare cases, maternal renal function may become seriously impaired, likely due to obstructive uropathy. Peripheral vascular resistance decreases in twin pregnancies. ( Option B ruled out) The blood volume also expands more than in singleton pregnancies, contributing to peripheral edema. This physiological adaptation ensures adequate blood flow and nutrient delivery to both fetuses. ( Option C ruled out) There is increased GFR. ( Option D ruled out) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 843

questions.question: A 28-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She is carrying dichorionic diamniotic twins. The first twin is in a cephalic presentation and delivers vaginally without complications. After the delivery of the first twin, the second twin is found to be in a transverse lie. Given the situation, the decision is made to perform an internal podalic version. Which of the following statements is true regarding internal podalic version in the context of twin pregnancy? breech delivery.

options.A: It is necessary if the second twin is in a breech presentation.
options.B: It involves converting the second twin to a cephalic presentation externally.
options.C: It is performed by reaching into the uterus to grasp and bring down the feet of the second twin for a
options.D: It is contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie for the second twin.

questions.explanation: the second twin for a breech delivery. reach into the uterus after the delivery of the first twin to grasp the feet of the second twin and convert it from a transverse lie to a breech presentation, allowing for vaginal delivery. It is necessary if second twin is in breech presentation (Option A) , if the second twin is already in a breech presentation, an internal podalic version is not needed. It involves converting the second twin to a cephalic presentation externally(Option B) as this describes the external cephalic version, not the internal podalic version. Internal podalic version is an internal maneuver. It is contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie for the second twin (Option D): Internal podalic version is not contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie; it is often indicated in such cases, especially in twin pregnancies to facilitate delivery.

questions.question: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation comes for her routine prenatal visit. She is expecting twins, and this is her first pregnancy. An ultrasound performed today shows that the first twin (Twin A) is in a cephalic presentation, while the second twin (Twin B) is in a breech presentation. Both fetuses have normal growth parameters and amniotic fluid indices, and there are no signs of fetal distress. The patient has no significant medical or obstetric history. What is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this patient?

options.A: Planned Cesarean section for both twins
options.B: Vaginal delivery for both twins, with a possible need for breech extraction for Twin B
options.C: Vaginal delivery for Twin A followed by an immediate Cesarean section for Twin B
options.D: External cephalic version for Twin B followed by a planned vaginal delivery for both twins

questions.explanation: Twin B presentation, normal vaginal delivery is attempted and breech extraction can be done for the second twin. Mode of Presentation & Delivery Both Cephalic (> 60%) or First Cephalic, 2 nd breech/ transverse - Normal vaginal delivery can be done. First Breech, 2 nd breech : Cesarean section First Breech, 2 nd cephalic : Cesarean section Interlocking of Twins Happens when 1 st Twin is in Breech, 2 nd Twin is Cephalic Very rarely seen Cord prolapse during twin delivery 1 st Twin Cephalic: Delivered 2 nd Twin Breech: High station → Cord Prolapse can happen: deliver immediately . Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 856-58

questions.question: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is undergoing her routine prenatal ultrasound at 18 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals she is carrying twins. Further assessment confirms that the twins share a single amniotic sac and a single fused placenta. Which of the following complications is most specific to this type of twin pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Cord entanglement due to the lack of a dividing membrane. This is not seen in monochorionic twins with separate amniotic sacs. Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) and selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR) (Option A and C ruled out) are complications more commonly associated with monochorionic twin pregnancies, where twins share a placenta. Selective IUGR (Option D ruled out) is specific to monochorionic twin pregnancy. Monoamniotic twins complications: Cord entanglement Birthweight discordance Monochorionic twins complications: Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS), and Twin reversed-arterial-perfusion (TRAP) sequence Selective IUGR Complications that occur in both monochorionic and monoamniotic twins: Preterm birth Congenital anomalies

questions.question: Which of the following is not a correct statement with respect to selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR)? ≥ 25% between the twins.

options.A: The fetal weight of one twin is less than the 10th percentile for normal fetuses.
options.B: There is a difference in weight of
options.C: Both twins have an unequal share of the placental mass.
options.D: MCA Doppler is used as the main modality of diagnosis in sIUGR.

questions.explanation: artery (MCA) Doppler. The classification and diagnosis of sIUGR involve assessing the characteristics of the umbilical artery Doppler flow for the IUGR fetus. Selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR) is a condition specific to monochorionic twin pregnancies where one twin exhibits significant growth restriction while the other twin grows normally . This disparity in growth is primarily due to unequal placental sharing , resulting in inadequate nutrient and blood supply to the growth-restricted twin.( Option C ruled out) Key Characteristics of sIUGR: Fetal Weight Criteria : The fetal weight of one twin is less than the 10th percentile for normal fetuses. (Option A ruled out) Weight Discrepancy : There is a significant difference in weight ( ≥ 25%) between the twins. (Option B ruled out) Reference: Elsevier selective intrauterine growth restriction in monochorionic twins

questions.question: Identify the diagnosis related to the image:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence Explanation: The image shows a typical presentation of Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence , characterized by an acardiac twin, an amorphous mass without a heart, and a normal twin. The acardiac twin receives blood from the normal twin via A-V anastomosis , which can lead to high-output cardiac failure in the normal twin. This deoxygenated blood, which keeps the recipient twin alive, however, goes only to the baby's lower limb, resulting in a mass of flesh with a very small head and properly formed lower limbs . There’s also an impending risk of cardiac failure in the donor baby as it is pumping blood to itself as well as into the recipient baby. Diagnosis is mainly done by USG Doppler or MRI . The main modality of treatment is by ligation of the umbilical cord (laser or RFA) of the acardiac twin under fetoscopic guidance. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 850 Journal of Clinical Imaging

questions.question: A 29-year-old pregnant woman with monochorionic diamniotic twins visits for a routine ultrasound at 32 weeks gestation. There is no significant difference in the weight or amniotic fluid volumes of the twins. Doppler studies show a significant difference in the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) between the twins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: significant difference in MCA PSV between the twins (Donor twin has an MCA PSV of >1.5 MoM, and the recipient twin has an MCA PSV of <1.0 MoM), without significant differences in their weight or amniotic fluid volumes . TAPS occurs due to unbalanced feto-fetal transfusion through minuscule placental anastomoses in monochorionic twin pregnancies, leading to Hb difference of ≥ 5gm % between the two twins. Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)(Option A) is incorrect because it typically involves significant differences in amniotic fluid volumes between the twins, with one twin having polyhydramnios and the other having oligohydramnios. Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP)Sequence(Option B) is incorrect because it involves an acardiac twin that is perfused by the pump twin, leading to reversed blood flow and a different clinical presentation. Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)(Option D) is incorrect because Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) involves significant growth restriction without the specific Doppler findings of differing MCA PSV seen in TAPS. Reference: Journal of Maternal Fetal Medicine

questions.question: All of the following can be management options for complicated cases of TTTS except?

options.A: Laser ablation of deep arteriovenous anastomosis
options.C: Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

questions.explanation: Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), so as to improve the survival chances of the recipient twin. Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) Definition TTTS is characterized by deep AV anastomosis between monochorionic twins. More common in MCDA>MCMA Clinical Findings Donor Twin : Oligohydramnios (<2 cm), anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, growth restriction, "stuck" appearance. Recipient Twin : Polyhydramnios (>8 cm), polycythemia, hypervolemia, hypertension, larger size, risk of heart failure and hydrops fetalis. Diagnostic Criteria Ultrasound Findings : MCDA twin pregnancy, discrepant amniotic fluid volumes, size discrepancy. Doppler Studies : Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery. Hematologic Findings : Hemoglobin difference >5 g%, estimated fetal weight discrepancy >25%. Management (Option A,B and D ruled out) Laser Ablation Amnioreduction Septostomy Selective Reduction of donor twin Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 848-49 Journal of Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynaecology

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Quintero staging system for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)? twin. donor twin.

options.A: Stage I is characterized by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery of the donor
options.B: Stage II is defined by the presence of polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and anhydramnios in the
options.C: Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.
options.D: Stage V indicates the presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.

questions.explanation: findings in one of both twins , such as Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, Reversed flow in the ductus venosus Pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein. Quintero Staging System for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) Stage Description Stage I (Option A ruled out) Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥ 8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤ 2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin. Stage II (Option B ruled out) The donor twin's bladder is not visible on ultrasound, indicating severe oligohydramnios. Stage III Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins Stage IV Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise Stage V (Option D ruled out) Demise of one or both twins Reference: Journal of Diagnostic Medical Sonography Donald School Journal of Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology

questions.question: All of the following are true regarding multifetal pregnancy, except:

options.A: Hellin's rule states that the incidence of twins is approximately 1 in 80 pregnancies.
options.B: Advanced maternal age increases the likelihood of multifetal pregnancy.
options.C: The use of fertility treatments can elevate the risk of multifetal pregnancy.
options.D: Multifetal pregnancies are associated with decreased risk of preterm birth.

questions.explanation: Overstretched uterus Excess amniotic fluid Early rupture of membrane According to Hellin’s rule: The incidence of twins is approximately 1 in 80 pregnancies. The incidence of triplets is approximately 1 in 80² (1 in 6,400) pregnancies. The incidence of quadruplets is approximately 1 in 80³ (1 in 512,000) pregnancies, and so on ( Option A ruled out). Older maternal age, particularly over 35, is associated with an increased likelihood of multifetal pregnancy, often due to increased ovulation of multiple eggs ( Option B ruled out). Fertility treatments such as ovulation induction and in vitro fertilization significantly increase the chances of multifetal pregnancies ( Option C ruled out). Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th Edition Pg 190-191

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman pregnant with monochorionic-diamniotic twins presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals no cardiac activity in one of the twins. The other twin has normal cardiac activity. Which of the following is a major complication in the surviving twin?
questions.explanation: Other complications include: Multicystic encephalomalacia Microcephaly renal cortical necrosis DIC This is likely due to the passage of thromboplastin from the deceased twin to the surviving twin via placental anastomoses and trigger a serious reaction. Oligohydramnios, Anemia, and Hypotension are the complications seen in Donor Twin in Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome. (Option A, C, D ruled out) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition Pg 375

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with a history of inability to conceive , presents at 12 weeks gestation following her first IVF cycle. Ultrasound confirms a quadruplet pregnancy. The doctor discusses multifetal reduction. Which of the following statements regarding fetal reduction is FALSE?

options.A: Improves the overall perinatal outcome in quadruplets
options.B: Potassium chloride is used in fetal reduction
options.C: Performed between 11 and 13 weeks of gestation
options.D: Monochorionic twin pregnancies are ideally suited for fetal reduction procedures

questions.explanation: procedures placenta and potential vascular connections between the twins, making them less ideal candidates for this procedure. In this scenario to improve the outcomes for the remaining fetuses, a selective reduction procedure may be performed to reduce the number of fetuses to two. This procedure is typically done between 11 and 13 weeks of pregnancy. (Option A,C ruled out) Selective fetal reduction is a procedure commonly used in multifetal pregnancies of higher order (3 or more) . Fetal reduction can be performed by injecting potassium chloride into the heart of the targeted fetus under ultrasound guidance. The procedure is transabdominal. (Option B ruled out) To protect the co-twin from the potential adverse effects of potassium chloride, the umbilical cord of the targeted twin is occluded. This can be done by fetoscopic ligation, laser, or bipolar coagulation. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 858-59

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins
options.B: Intrauterine death of one fetus is more in dizygotic twins
options.C: Fetal anomalies are more commonly seen in dizygotic twins
options.D: Fetal complications in multifetal pregnancy doesn't depend on chorionicity

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins Explanation: Discordant twin growth is a common complication of multifetal pregnancy. An estimated weight difference of 25% or more is considered true pathological discordance. Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins. Discordance may be due to twin-twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency, IUGR, or structural anomalies occurring in one fetus. Foetal Complications in Multifetal Pregnancies Increased Miscarriage Rate More common in monozygotic twins. High Premature Birth Rate 80% occurrence, with associated risks. Discordant Twin Growth 20% prevalence, with pathological discordance ( ≥ 25% weight difference). Causes: Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), placental insufficiency, intrauterine growth restriction, structural anomalies. Increased Intrauterine Foetal Death More common in monozygotic twins. (Option B ruled out) First Trimester: Vanishing twin through resorption. Second Trimester: Fetus papyraceous (mummified foetus). Late Pregnancy: Risks to surviving twin or maternal disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Appearing Twin Phenomenon A twin initially missed on ultrasound but detected later, more common in monozygotic twins. Increased Foetal Anomalies 2-4% higher risk in monozygous twins than in singleton pregnancies. (Option C ruled out) Includes anencephaly, holoprosencephaly, neural tube defects, symmelia, microcephaly, cardiac anomalies and Down’s syndrome. Higher Risk of Asphyxia and Stillbirth Increased risk due to pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placental abruption, and operative interventions. The second twin is at higher risk. Specific Complications in Monozygotic/Monochorionic Twins: Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) Occurs in 10-15% of monozygotic twins due to placental vascular anastomosis. Dead Foetus Syndrome 2-7% occurrence, with a 25% risk of poor outcomes for the surviving twin. Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) High risk of perinatal death from cardiac failure in the healthy twin; chromosomal abnormalities in the perfused twin. Monoamniotic Twins High perinatal mortality due to cord entanglement, low birth weight and congenital anomalies. Fetal complications in multifetal pregnancy are more in the monochorionic type as compared to dichorionic, thus depend on chorionicity (Option D ruled out). Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 841, 845-50

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation, conceived via in vitro fertilization (IVF) is now carrying dichorionic-diamniotic twins. She reports increasing discomfort and shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the least likely complication in her pregnancy ?
questions.explanation: DCDA) due to sharing of placenta & in those with problematic deep arterio-venous connections between the placentas. Such connections are more often encountered in MCDA twins rather than MCMA twins. Maternal Complications can be divided into 3 stages: Pregnancy Labor Puerperium Pregnancy Labor Puerperium Nausea, vomiting Anemia PIH and pre-eclampsia Polyhydramnios/ oligohydramnios Preterm labo r Malpresentation Antepartum hemorrhage Mechanical distress (dyspnea, palpitation) Prolonged labor Operative interference Postpartum hemorrhage Subinvolution Infection Lactation failure Preterm labor occurs frequently (in 50% of cases) in twin pregnancies, with twins typically being delivered around 37 weeks gestation on average. The causes include excessive stretching of the uterus, increased amniotic fluid (hydramnios), and premature rupture of membranes The risk of pre-eclampsia is three times higher in twin pregnancies, possibly due to increased exposure to an excess of chorionic villi Malpresentation is more frequent in twins compared to single pregnancies. Approximately 70% of the time, the first baby presents headfirst (vertex), and in 50% of cases, both babies present headfirst. Therefore, malpresentation is more commonly observed in the second baby Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 843-845

questions.question: During a chorionicity scan in a twin pregnancy, which imaging finding would indicate Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins?

options.A: Visualization of two distinct placentas and separate amniotic sacs
options.B: Detection of a single placenta and two separate amniotic sacs
options.C: Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac
options.D: Observation of two placentas and a single shared amniotic sac

questions.explanation: Monochorionic-monoamniotic pregnancy as MCMA twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac. Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound (TVS) at 11–14 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins there is a thick septum (>2 mm) between the two gestational sacs. It is best identified at the base of the membrane, where a triangular projection is seen. This is due to extension of chorionic villi into the potential inter chorionic space. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. Presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates dichorionic placenta. Presence of one gestational sac with a thin (<2 mm) dividing membrane, and two fetuses, (‘T’ sign) suggests monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. A. ‘Twin peak’ sign: In dichorionic diamniotic twin gestations , the chorion and amnion for each twin reflect away from the fused placenta to form the intertwin membrane. A potential space exists in the intertwin membrane, filled by proliferating placental villi giving rise to the twin peak sign. The twin peak sign appears as a triangle with the base at the chorionic surface and the apex in the intertwin membrane. B. In monochorionic, diamniotic twins , the intertwin membrane only comprises two amnions. C. Color Doppler scan (TVS) showing twin pregnancy. A thick intertwin membrane (twin peak sign) of the dichorionic, diamniotic placenta is seen. This finding indicates a Dichorionic-Diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy, where each twin has its own placenta and amniotic sac. (Option A ruled out) This describes a Monochorionic-Diamniotic (MCDA) twin pregnancy, where twins share a placenta but have separate amniotic sacs. (Option B ruled out) This scenario is not physiologically possible in twin pregnancies; twins cannot share a single amniotic sac if they have separate placentas. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Dichorionic-Diamniotic (DCDA), Monochorionic-Diamniotic (MCDA), and Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins? separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both a chorion and an amnion. amnion, and MCMA twins have separate chorions and amniotic sacs. separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both chorion and amnion. chorion and amnion, and MCDA twins share both chorion and amnion.

options.A: DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, while MCDA twins share a chorion but have
options.B: DCDA twins share a chorion and an amnion, MCDA twins each have their own chorion but share an
options.C: MCDA twins have separate placentas and amniotic sacs, DCDA twins share a chorion but have
options.D: MCMA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, DCDA twins each have their own

questions.explanation: a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both a chorion and an amnion. having its own chorion and amnion. MCDA twins split later (between 4-7 days) and share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs. MCMA twins result from a later split (between 8-12 days), sharing both the chorion and amnion. Timing of Cleavage Placenta & Membrane Status < 72 hours Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac. Days 4–7 Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs. Days 8–12 Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Ed, Pg. 839-40

questions.question: Which type of monozygotic twins develops when the zygote splits very early, usually within the first 3 days after fertilization, resulting in separate placentas and amniotic sacs for each twin?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Dichorionic-diamniotic twins Explanation: Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac, forming when the zygote splits early, typically within the first 3 days after fertilization. Zygosity Chorionicity Zygosity refers to the genetic makeup of twin pregnancies. Monozygotic twins originate from a single fertilized egg that splits into two, leading to genetically identical individuals. Chorionicity refers to the placenta’s membrane status. Chorionicity is determined by the timing of embryo division. Timing of Cleavage Placenta & Membrane Status < 72 hours (Option C) Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac. Days 4–7 (Option A) Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs. Days 8–12 (Option B) Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac. Day > 13 (Option D) Conjoined (Siamese) are physically connected and may share organs or tissues, resulting from a very late and incomplete split.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes superfetation in the context of twin formation? the same gestational age but different fathers. gestational ages. twins. gestational age.

options.A: The fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle, possibly resulting in twins of
options.B: The occurrence of a second pregnancy while already carrying a fetus, leading to twins of different
options.C: The fertilization of a single ovum by two different sperm cells, resulting in a rare form of identical
options.D: The splitting of a single fertilized egg into two embryos, leading to identical twins of the same

questions.explanation: twins of different gestational ages. pregnancy, resulting in twins with different gestational ages. Heteropaternal superfecundation occurs when two eggs from the same cycle are fertilized by sperm from different instances of intercourse. (Option A ruled out) The fertilization of a single ovum by two different sperm cells is an extremely rare phenomenon known as sesquizygotic twinning or heterogynic twinning . (Option C ruled out) Monozygotic or identical twins , where a single fertilized egg divides into two embryos, not related to superfetation. (Option D ruled out)
